snippet.textDisplay:
Wow, so many naive people in the comments comparing this book to Harry Potter. First of all, I think it’s ridiculous to criticize this book simply because she’s white. I have yet to read the book so I can’t defend it either. I can understand how someone’s actual experience can be insulted by someone’s else’s description of it because they didn’t actually go through it therefore can never do it justice. I’m hearing she did research which is great but you can’t research feelings and thoughts. You either went through it or you didn’t. So I can understand how some might be offended. To me though, the bigger picture is seeing the targeted audience getting exposed to something real that maybe a Hispanic author might not have been able to reach. So I think it’s unfair to try and “cancel” her and the book.
With that being said, I find the Harry Potter comparisons naive and unsympathetic.
Fact: Harry Potter is fiction. Period.
“American Dirt” is only fictional because it’s not her autobiography (which is why it’s so controversial).
FACT: The topic of her book is VERY REAL. Don’t compare running through a magical brick wall at a train station to people dangerously crossing the border.

snippet.textDisplay: Harriet Beecher Stowe wrote “Uncle Tom’s Cabin”. She was a white woman writing about the slave experience. She was not writing for slaves. She was writing for the people who needed to help bring change. This is not to suggest that there were not unfortunate stereotypes in “Uncle Tom’s Cabin”, there were, but that small, flawed book was powerful, influential and helpful. It spoke to people who would never heard the voices of the slaves.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't mind that the author is white but I do mind the weird promotion they did of her and her husband. Like describing the book as a telling of a "real latinex migrant story." I haven't read it but I'm concerned as a daughter of migrants that the book will sugarcoat and stereotype experiences that brown people face when crossing the Mexican border. I myself don't know the full extent of suffering because my mother never wants to spare me to know all the details. What I do know is the journey is one of danger and being constantly chased by everything which includes border patrol, the elements, your own exhaustion, and the things you are escaping from your original country. It is non stop and if you're unlucky you'll find the bodies of mothers and children and babies who lost their lives trying to better them. Each story is different but each one includes tragedy and that's something I wish more people understood.

snippet.textDisplay:
"LatinX" is a travesty of language. Pronouns are used for all objects in Latin-based languages, like Spanish of French. The chair is a "She" and the ceiling is a "He", there is no way around it.
If you truly want to be inclusive by not using "Latino/Latina", then "LatinX" is not the way to go.
Simply say "Latin", no need for the X. It is grammatically correct. It is stupid to try and change the whole Grammar of a language just to be inclusive for non-binary people or whatever.
Just stop with the assault on language, English is an exception, having no pronouns for objects.
You americans need to chill the fuck out and stop trying to make everything into politics.
Grammar is not part of politics.
Grammar is not subjective.
Languages have rules for a reason.
Stop making everything revolve around your politics.

Coronavirus is not under control at all, neither in China or the rest of the world. In Canada they only checked people with symptoms. We could be looking at 3000+ dormant, untraceable cases before symptoms even begin to show...

Then there's the concern over mutation. The spanish Flu wasn't very deadly at first, but then the virus mutated and killed 30-40 million people worldwide.

snippet.textDisplay:
Good luck selling a book about only white people and white people problems these days.

Writing is a form of artistic expression. Something I don’t think should be limited by anything. If people want a medium to give their thoughts some physical form, allow them. Let them sell it to see if people are interested in reading in. If a white person sells a book about an immigrant and it sells well, it’s sending the message that this person has a perspective that people want to hear. Maybe it isn’t entirely accurate because this person is white, but since when was every writer expected to be 100% accurate? Does every writer need to have a masters degree in race studies in order to write a book that involves anyone who isn’t their race? Where do you draw the line? I don’t see any reason to restrict someone’s ability to express themselves artistically, and I don’t think anyone has the right to dictate what stories we are allowed to buy, enjoy or recommend to others. No race has the exclusive right to tell a story, period.

snippet.textDisplay:
Here's the thing about that whole "White people can't write about brown people" thing. It's untrue. If you are born and raised in a culture, you are part of that culture and have every bit of knowledge as anyone with a different skin tone. Now, I know Jeanine is a different situation, she is a Spaniard who move to NYC. I get it. But the common outrage is that broad stroke that "White people aren't allowed to tell stories about other cultures."

Culture is a learned trait. No one born Latino is born with the knowledge of their culture. They learn it through the environment they grow up in. I'm Latino, but my best friend (I call him my brother) is white. He's 100% German ancestry. But that dude is just as, if not more, Mexican than I am. Why? He was born in the same ghetto I was, raised in the same community, went to the same schools and attended the same city sponsored cultural events. He stood up in several Quinceanera's. He learned how to dance cumbia at school dances. He didn't get a taste of the culture of his ancestors till he was in college and had a chance to travel. Hell, growing up white in brown town USA, he experiences much more real racism than me.

If he were to write a book about a Mexican immigrant I'm 100% confident it would be absolutely authentic. I'm also certain that all you ignorant assholes would be screaming cultural appropriation when you saw his name on the cover. "Racial identity" is complete bullshit. It's where and how we are raised. You don't have to be Mexican to understand Mexican culture. You don't have to be Irish to tell a story about Irish culture. A story is a story. If someone does their homework, invests in the culture at the center of their story, then they can tell that story. Period.

He learned how to dance cumbia at school dances. He didn't get a taste of the culture of his ancestors till he was in college and had a chance to travel. Hell, growing up white in brown town USA, he experiences much more real racism than me. 

If he were to write a book about a Mexican immigrant I'm 100% confident it would be absolutely authentic. I'm also certain that all you ignorant assholes would be screaming cultural appropriation when you saw his name on the cover. "Racial identity" is complete bullshit. It's where and how we are raised. You don't have to be Mexican to understand Mexican culture. You don't have to be Irish to tell a story about Irish culture. A story is a story.  If someone does their homework, invests in the culture at the center of their story, then they can tell that story. Period.

snippet.textDisplay:
I haven't read the book and won't read the book because that's not the genre I'm particularly interested in, but I'm kind of curious to know if the author had used a fake name/was anonymous if the writing would have stood out as "ah yes, a mayonnaise person definitely wrote this" or are people seeing her being white and immediately hating on the book based on that/what others have said?
Yes it would be better if someone who actually went through it wrote it. But to say nobody can write about a topic unless having personal experience or the "right" skin color when there are vast materials to research a subject, especially when it's a work of FICTION? Bit ridiculous imo.
I think Oprah should keep the book in her club because it brings up a good conversation, but maybe she should also offer a partnership to get someone with the passion to write to write their own real life experience.

Nobody needs to agree or disagree to this comment, just throwing random thoughts out.

snippet.textDisplay:
Well in regards to the books, it's been a problem in how they did it. The author got a 1mil advance pay when well thought latinx literature gets little to nothing. But the main question is she can't be the first person to create a story like this, right? Where is the amount of effort put into this author for a "legitimate" story?
There was also the problem with the writer "embracing" her heritage after the fact when it was convenient for her. Phil briefly mentioned it but it was passed off.

Then, supposedly, there are moments in the book that use Spanish incorrectly. Abuelita=mother
The author showed little to no accurate research in the book.

The controversy is far beyond just who wrote the book. It's the attitude of how they went around it, and who benefited what.

snippet.textDisplay: My main issue about the book stuff is how on one hand people keep saying we should have more diversity in books, yet when people try, especially white people, there tends to be backlash over “you shouldn’t be the one writing this”. Yes, stereotypes shouldn’t be used, and people need to do more research, but if we attack everyone who tries then who’s going to want to try anymore? Constructive criticism is good but sometimes it goes too far.
